Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Azure Search] Use synonym mapping for improving search results" (#7122) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We could potentially use synonym mappings for improving know search queries, for eg: searching for database could also include "sql", "nosql", "table storage" etc as the search terms. Azure search provides a way to map these keywords together using Synonym maps which could potentially be helpful.

This work can be done in the future for search improvements.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "web.config compilation->debug should be set to false" (#7121) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "web.config compilation->debug should be set to false" (#7121) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Encourage usage of nuget.org V3 API instead of V2" (#7120) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

When using new client tools (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe) but configuring nuget.org URL to be V2 (https://nuget.org/api/v2) users don't get new features that are V3 dependent:  blue checkmark, repo signing, symbol publishing, license expressions, deprecation, etc. They also don't take advantage of better perf and reliability.

We should get people to use V3 for nuget.org (https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json)

**Some ideas to achieve this:**
1. Tell nuget.org push clients to upgrade to v3 protocol (or to upgrade client versions when possible) (we could have slightly different URIs for v3 redirect to push.)
2. Client can discover from a v2 feed that a v3 feed exists. Expose informational or warning or error (controlled by server)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Azure Search] Test gallery circuit breaker again new search service" (#7119) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Both the region down case and the intermittent failure case.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Increase API rate limit" (#6732) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Now it's 250 packages/hour. Given our perf improvements, we can increase to 350 per hour (or more?)
We should think if this should be done for push alone or unlist as well.

Should also update documentation:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/rate-limits

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Store users preferred tab in localStorage" (#7098) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Reopened issue "JsonRuntimeFormat writes excessive data" (#4717) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I was porting some code from an old DNX copy of the RuntimeJson format stuff to use NuGet.RuntimeModel instead and noticed a couple differences.

- NuGet writes an empty `#import` array when there aren't any imports.
- NuGet writes open ended version ranges as `[versionMin, )` instead of `versionMin`

I've worked around both of these to maintain the same file format as before but wanted to make you aware of them.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Props and target files in build\native are not referenced in vcxproj" (#8078) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: nuget.exe, "msbuild /restore" (16.x)

NuGet version: 4.9.3.5777

OS version: Win10 v1809

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Add reference: `<PackageReference Include="rapidjson" Version="1.0.2" IncludeAssets="all" PrivateAssets="all" />`

2. Run: `nuget restore` on solution

The generated project.assets.json has solution-level package references from a Directory.Build.props higher up, but does not reference the `build\native\rapidjson.targets` as nuget.exe (same version) did with packages.config prior to migration.

Here's a snippet of project.assets.json:
```json
      "Nerdbank.GitVersioning/2.3.125": {
        "type": "package",
        "build": {
          "build/Nerdbank.GitVersioning.targets": {}
        },
        "buildMultiTargeting": {
          "buildCrossTargeting/Nerdbank.GitVersioning.targets": {}
        }
      },
      "rapidjson/1.0.2": {
        "type": "package"
      },
      "Roslyn.Diagnostics.Analyzers/2.6.3": {
        "type": "package",
        "build": {
          "build/Roslyn.Diagnostics.Analyzers.props": {}
        }
      },
```

The files are known, however:
```json
    "rapidjson/1.0.2": {
      "sha512": "uYKgq5H2pC6yOjjRQKjXsOFiOrO4bPWwQBiOS3fH/5+u/PuB9ZoA1/OZfmybGa68RURhZhmyvB3kcmyQnhIqmg==",
      "type": "package",
      "path": "rapidjson/1.0.2",
      "files": [
        ".nupkg.metadata",
        "build/configurations.autopkg",
        "build/native/default-propertiesui.xml",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/allocators.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/document.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/encodedstream.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/encodings.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/error/en.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/error/error.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/filereadstream.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/filewritestream.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/biginteger.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/diyfp.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/dtoa.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/ieee754.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/itoa.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/meta.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/pow10.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/stack.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/strfunc.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/internal/strtod.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/memorybuffer.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/memorystream.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/msinttypes/inttypes.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/msinttypes/stdint.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/prettywriter.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/rapidjson.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/reader.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/stringbuffer.h",
        "build/native/include/rapidjson/writer.h",
        "build/native/rapidjson.targets",
        "build/publisher-info.txt",
        "rapidjson.1.0.2.nupkg.sha512",
        "rapidjson.nuspec"
      ]
    },
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Encourage usage of nuget.org V3 API instead of V2" (#8079) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

When using new client tools (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe) but configuring nuget.org URL to be V2 (https://nuget.org/api/v2) users don't get new features that are V3 dependent:  blue checkmark, repo signing, symbol publishing, license expressions, deprecation, etc. They also don't take advantage of better perf and reliability.

We should get people to use V3 for nuget.org (https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json)

**Some ideas to achieve this:**
1. Make it a warning if v2 nuget.org source is used
2. Encourage moving to V3 in VS UI

Related to https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7120 with server side ideas.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuget Packages getting auto removed" (#8017) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
With the VS2019 Preview 2.2, every time I add a nuget package to my application, it stays for a bit but it seems like after I start a debug and end it, the nuget package gets removed or if it was an upgrade, it gets reverted back down to the previous version. _This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/447942/nuget-packages-getting-auto-removed.html VSTS ticketId: 788339_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Brad on 2/11/2019, 04:41 PM (65 days ago): Also experiencing this.

Package reference added via Package Manager window.

Subsequently, I am also unable to double-click the project file or use the context menu command "Edit .csproj" to open the netstandard2.0 csproj.

I have attached the output from the Package Manager output window.
Brad on 2/11/2019, 04:56 PM (65 days ago):

Upon restarting VS, when attempting to edit the project files, the following error is displayed

An exception has been encountered. This may be caused by an extension.

You can get more information by examining the file 'C:\Users\removed\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\VisualStudio\16.0_eeb51662\ActivityLog.xml'.


ActivityLog.xml shared in subsequent comment (privately)

Brad on 2/11/2019, 05:15 PM (65 days ago):

activitylogxml.txt

Russ Painter on 3/20/2019, 06:56 AM (29 days ago): It doesn't matter if I add from the Package Manager Console or from the Package Manager UI, the changes don't get applied to my csproj. I switch back to VS2017 on the same project, and either of those methods work perfectly to add packages to my project.

Once the packages are added to the csproj, I can return to VS2019 and evertying works fine, until I need to add another package. Russ Painter on 3/20/2019, 06:57 AM (29 days ago): Restarting VS2019 does not fix the problem in my case. Brent Robinson on 3/29/2019, 11:49 PM (19 days ago): Agreed. It looks like the csproj file is being reverted to an earlier state when adding a NuGet package. In my case I added a NuGet package, and couldn't open the csproj in VS2019. I closed VS, made other changes to the csproj outside of VS, then commited to source control. I noticed the package wasn't added, so added it via VS2019. It didn't add the package, but it did revert my csproj file to the state before VS2019 was opened.

I was able to work around this by
1. Close VS2019
2. Delete the ".vs" folder
3. Open VS2019, add the NuGet package
4. Save all

I suspect "Save all" after adding a NuGet package might be key here. Ben Rothermel on 4/15/2019, 04:02 AM (3 days ago):

Experiencing this in the latest stable VS2019 release

Alexander Witkowski on 4/17/2019, 00:39 PM (21 hours ago): Have the same issue with:

Events.RelatedBody: In Visual Studio, when you search for package for a package, you should be able to see in the package info view, a link back to the NuGet Gallery. Since the Gallery may contain information that isn't present in VS it would be helpful to users to be able to navigate to the Gallery to find out more.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Provide a disk clean-up option" (#8076) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The NuGet cache should be listed in the Disk Clean-up entries. I am reaching low disk space every now and then while NuGet cache is happily eating gigabytes of unneeded data.

As far as I can tell from [Creating a Disk Cleanup Handler](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/lwef/disk-cleanup#example-registration-of-a-disk-cleanup-handler), a simple registry entry might do without any code required, e.g.:
```
Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00

[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\VolumeCaches\NuGet Cache Files]
@="{C0E13E61-0CC6-11d1-BBB6-0060978B2AE6}"
"Description"="Whenever you install, update, or restore a package, NuGet manages packages and package information in several folders outside of your project structure. Cleans the default global-packages, http-cache, temp, plugins-cache and package-cache locations."
"Display"="NuGet Cache"
"FileList"="*.*"
"Flags"=dword:00000059
"Folder"="%userprofile%\\.nuget\\packages|%localappdata%\\NuGet\\v3-cache|%localappdata%\\NuGet\\plugins-cache|%localappdata%\\NuGet\\Cache"
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10546952/57014828-adece600-6c09-11e9-9281-da17c9959c40.png)

Alternatively (or in addition), the `CleanupString` can be used to invoke `nuget locals all -clear` to handle location overrides, provided the path to `nuget` is known.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget list & add commands are being deprecated in 5.0" (#34) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Tracking Issue(s):
* Deprecate ambiguous nuget.exe commands in 5.0 [#7753](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7753)
  * Deprecate nuget.exe add command [#7923](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7923)
  * Rename nuget.exe list to nuget.exe search [#7912](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7912)

The following commands are being deprecated because these are cause of confusion due to their nomenclature and/or other related commands that already exist:
* [`nuget list`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-list): Currently displays a list of packages from a given source
  * This will be replaced by an equivalent command **`nuget search`** which will be later enhanced with more capabilities as we make progress with or [search improvements](nvmd got it: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6371​​​​​​​).
* [`nuget add`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-add): Currently adds a specified package to a non-HTTP package source (a folder or UNC path) in a hierarchical layout, wherein folders are created for the package ID and version number. 
  * This will be replaced by overloading **`nuget push`** command.

> These commands will be deprecated i.e. there will be a warning on usage of these commands in 5.0 so that in future releases these commands can be discontinued.
